I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Inner Mongolia Road Development Project. The 
report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Restoration  of Wetlands  in  Dalai 
Lake  National  Nature  Reserve  of  Inner  Mongolia  Autonomous  Region,  and  if  the  Board 
approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board, 
approve the TA.1 

2. 
The following activities will be undertaken under the project: (i) upgrade a section of the 
provincial highway in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (IMAR) of the PRC, (ii) upgrade rural 
roads, (iii) facilitate cross-border transport and trade, (iv) support community-based sustainable 
tourism and environmental conservation, and (v) strengthen institutional capacity.2  

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

3. 
IMAR  is  the  third-largest  administrative  region  of  the  PRC  in  terms  of  land  area  and  is 
well endowed with natural resources. As a result of mining, IMAR’s economy has been growing 
rapidly,  with  gross  domestic  product  increasing  at  18%  per  annum  from  2003  to  2011.  The 
proposed  project  is  located  in  Hulunbeier,  one  of  the  fast-growing  areas  of  IMAR.3 Hulunbeier 
covers  253,000  square  kilometers  and  is  very  sparsely  populated  (fewer  than  4  million 
inhabitants). It borders the PRC’s Heilongjiang province, the Russian Federation, and Mongolia. 
Its economy depends heavily on resource extraction industries (coal, oil, and various minerals), 
animal  husbandry,  trade  with  the  Russian  Federation  and  to  a  lesser  extent  Mongolia,  and  a 
developing  tourism  industry.  Considerable  infrastructure  improvements  are  needed  to  support 
further economic growth. 

4. 
The demand for transport in IMAR has grown in line with economic growth. Rail freight 
increased  from  181  million  tons  in  2005  to  646  million  tons  in  2011.  Similarly,  highway  freight 
traffic  increased  from  510  million  tons  in  2005  to  more  than  1  billion  tons  in  2011.  Road 
conditions  in  IMAR  are  lagging  behind  the  rest  of  the  PRC.  In  2010,  the  Inner  Mongolia 
Autonomous Region Department of Transport (IMDT) estimated that only 58.5% of the region’s 
roads  were  in  good  or  excellent  condition,  against  the  national  average  of  75.8%.  There  is  a 
backlog of roads needing rehabilitation or upgrades. IMAR needs to prioritize upgrades to cater 
for increased traffic and increase maintenance financing to ensure sustainability. 

5. 
Provincial  highway  S203.  The  main  road  in  Hulunbeier  is  provincial  highway  S203, 
which  starts  at  Manzhouli  city  and  is  496 kilometers  (km)  long. The  section from  Manzhouli  to 
Alatanemole  conforms  to  PRC  highway  class  III  standard4 and  is  in  relatively  poor  condition. 
There  are  numerous  sections  where  the  pavement  is  buckling  and  settling,  which  limits 
operating  speeds.  Traffic  on  the  road  is  mainly  trucks  to  and  from  regional  land  ports;  trucks 
carrying timber, coal, and other minerals; agricultural vehicles; tourist and local buses; and local

 private  vehicles.  The  development  of  a  new  industrial  park  south  of  Manzhouli  is  expected  to 
lead to further traffic growth, including heavy trucks on the provincial highway. The existing road 
will not be able to handle the projected volume of traffic.  

Regional integration and cross-border transport. The principal border-crossing point 
6. 
for  the  region  is  on  the  Russian  Federation’s  border  at  Manzhouli,  which  handles  60%  of  the 
PRC’s  overland  trade  with  the  Russian  Federation.  The  two  border-crossing  points  with 
Mongolia—at  Arihasate  and  Ebuduge—are  well  established  and  are  expected  to  grow 
significantly in the future. PRC-based companies are actively pursuing potential projects across 
the  border  in  Mongolia,  which  is  expected  to  lead  to  increased  import  traffic.  However,  within 
IMAR, connectivity with these border crossings is inadequate. Existing roads are narrow and in 
poor condition and cannot support movement of heavy trucks. The roads to the border-crossing 
points also need to be improved because they include links to the Asian Highway network.5 The 
Choibalsan–Manzhouli–Chita  corridor,  mainly  consisting  of  provincial  highway  S203,  is 
potentially  a  key  conduit  between  Asian  highway  routes  AH6  and  AH32, giving  shippers  more 
route choices  and motivating  countries  to  compete for transit traffic. The  planned  extension  of 
the  Alatanemole–Arihasate  road  to  Choibalsan  and  beyond  to  Ulaanbaatar  in  Mongolia  will 
strengthen  regional  links  as  it  will  connect  to  Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation 
corridor 4b, which is also Asian highway route AH3. 

Road  safety.  Road  safety  is  a  major  problem  in  the  PRC,  with  an  estimated  210,000 
7. 
accidents and 62,000 fatalities in 2011. In IMAR, the accident rate in 2009 was 9.4 fatalities per 
100,000 people, nearly twice the PRC average of 5.1. Accidents are also more severe in IMAR, 
with  the ratio  of fatalities  to  injuries  being four  times  higher  than  in  the  rest  of  the  PRC.  Road 
conditions  are  a  major  determinant  of  IMAR’s  higher  accident  rates,  particularly  on  medium-
class roads (class III). Because of the flatness of the plains, these roads have good geometry, 
enabling  speeds  of  up  to  120  km  per  hour.  However,  they  also  tend  to  be  narrow,  lack 
shoulders,  and  are  elevated  above the  plain  without  safety  barriers. These factors  make them 
potentially dangerous, especially when high speeds are involved.  

8. 
Rural  roads.  The  region  is  home  to  a  number  of  ethnic  minorities  who  live  in  small 
villages  and  towns,  most  of  which  can  only  be  accessed  via  unpaved  roads  which  become 
treacherous during winter. The hardships of extreme cold are compounded by the occurrence of 
snowstorms  and  blizzards.  The  low  population  density  implies  that  the  region  requires  a 
relatively  large  stock  of  road  infrastructure  compared  to  other  parts  of  the  PRC  in  order  to 
ensure access for isolated communities. However, road density per 1,000 square kilometers is 
only 139 km, as against the PRC average of 426 km. Providing paved roads will improve access 
to jobs, education, and health services for poor rural communities. 

9. 
Environmental  conservation. Hulunbeier has some of the largest and most significant 
grassland  and  wetland  ecosystems  in  the  region.  A  major  geographical  feature  in  the 
Hulunbeier landscape is Dalai Lake, one of the five largest freshwater lakes in the PRC. Dalai 
Lake  and  associated  wetland  and  grassland  ecosystems  form  part  of  the  Dalai  Lake  National 
Nature  Reserve  (NNR). Since  2000  there  has  been  a general  pattern  of falling  water  levels  in 
Dalai lake and shallow water wetlands and marshes have become desiccated. Increases in the 
numbers  of  visitors  and  tourists  entering  the  NNR  are  also  expected  to  increase  pressure  on 
natural  resources,  habitats,  and  species  within  the  reserve.  The  Dalai  Lake  National  Nature

 Reserve  Management Bureau (NNR Bureau) needs to strengthen protection and conservation 
of the reserve and promote sustainable tourism activities. 

10. 
Climate  change.  Hulunbeier  is  in  the  southernmost  area  of  the  northern  hemisphere 
permafrost zone and has discontinuous and/or sporadic permafrost.6 It is expected that climate 
change  will  lead  to  thawing  of  permafrost  which  can  threaten  the  structural  integrity  of  road 
infrastructure.  Infrastructure  projects  in  the  region  need  to  factor-in  climate  change  during  the 
planning and design phases to ensure that the projects are climate resilient. 

The  project  will  address  aforementioned  regional  development, 

11. 
transport,  and 
environmental  needs.  It  will  also  support  the  government’s  Western  Region  Development 
Strategy7 and Northeast Region and Other Old Industrial Bases Revitalization Strategy.8 It is in 
line  with  ADB’s  objectives  in  the  country  partnership  strategy9 and  its  support  for  road  safety, 
rural  roads,  environmental  conservation,  and  cross-border  transport  aligns  it  with  the  core 
objectives of ADB’s Sustainable Transport Initiative.10

12.

assistance to improve community facilities.12 These lessons were reflected in the project design 
in  that  (i)  guidance  was  provided  to  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  on  ADB 
procedures  on  safeguards  and  procurement;  (ii)  extensive  community  consultation  was 
undertaken during project preparation; and (iii) facilities for communities, such as procurement 
of  rescue  and  relief  equipment  for  use  during  extreme  weather  events,  were  included  in  the 
project design.  

The  project  design  also  drew  upon  ADB’s  2007  sector  assistance  program  evaluation

following  value-addition  components:  (i)  safer  road  designs  to  ensure  that  project  roads  and 
bridges conform to best practices in road safety, (ii) upgrades of roads to border-crossing points 
and trade facilitation to improve regional trade links, (iii) bus terminals and bus stops in project

B. 

Impact and Outcome 

The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  the  efficient,  inclusive,  and  safe  movement  of  people 
14. 
and  goods  in  IMAR  and  across  the  borders  of  the  Russian  Federation  and  Mongolia.  The 
project  outcome  will  be  the  development  of  a  safe  and  efficient  road  transport  network  that 
supports environmental conservation and sustainable tourism.

C. 

Outputs 

15. 
The  project  will  finance  five  main  outputs  intended  to  develop  the  road  network  in 
Hulunbeier  and  provide  support  for  cross-border  trade,  sustainable  tourism,  environmental 
conservation, and institutional strengthening and capacity building. 

16. 
Output  1: Highway  upgrading  and  road  safety  improvement. This output comprises 
(i) upgrading approximately 132 km of provincial highway from Manzhouli to Alatanemole from 
class  III 14  to  half-class-I  standard; 15  and  (ii)  improving  safety  of  the  provincial  highway  by 
introducing  measures  including  road  markings,  signage,  speed  controlled  junction  design, 
barriers and underpasses for animals, designated parking, viewing points, and service areas. 

Output 2: Upgrading of rural roads. This output comprises upgrading (i) approximately 
17. 
66 km of a natural (unclassified) road from Xinboluke to Manzhouli to class III, (ii) approximately 
127  km  of  a  sand  and  stone  unclassified  road  from  Nuogannuoer  through  Wubuerbaolige  to 
Alantanhadagacha to class IV, (iii) approximately 54 km of a sand and stone unclassified road 
connecting Baogedewula with Beiersumu to class IV, and (iv) approximately 45 km of a natural 
unclassified road from Amugulang to Wubuerbaolige to class III.  

18. 
Output  3:  Cross-border  transport  improvement  and  trade  facilitation.  This  output 
comprises  (i)  rehabilitation  and  upgrade  of  approximately  82  km  of  the  class  III  road  from 
Alatanemole  to  Arihasate  border-crossing  point  to  class  II,  (ii)  rehabilitation  and  upgrade  of 
approximately 22 km of the class III road from Amugulang to Ebuduge border-crossing point to 
class  II, (iii)  construction  of  bus stops  and  terminals  in  Hulunbeier,  and (iv)  cross-border  trade 
facilitation between the PRC and Mongolia.16 

19. 
Output  4:  Support  for  community-based  sustainable  tourism  and  environmental 
conservation.  This  output  comprises  (i)  construction  of  rest  areas  and  installation  of  signage 
and  information  boards  along  the  S203  to  reduce  uncontrolled  driving  and  parking  in 
environmentally  sensitive  areas;  (ii)  development  of  an  eco-cultural  trail  to  enable  tourists  to 
experience grasslands, wetlands, and traditional lifestyle; and (iii) support for the NNR Bureau, 
including construction of a multipurpose protection center; provision of equipment for protection, 
research,  and  monitoring;  and  assistance  in  the  development  of  the  10-year  master  plan  for 
habitat management, eco-tourism development, and habitat restoration.  

20. 
Output  5:  Institutional  strengthening  and  capacity  building. This  output  comprises 
(i)  project  management and  implementation  support to  ensure compliance  with  ADB’s  policies 
and procedures; (ii) capacity building of the project executing agency and implementing agency 
in  road  safety,  operation,  and  maintenance;  and  (iii)  capacity  building  of  NNR  Bureau  staff  to 
improve management of the nature reserve.

Implementation Arrangements 

24. 
The  executing  agency  will  be  the  IMDT  and  the  implementing  agency  will  be  the 
Hulunbeier  Bureau  of  Transport.  A  project  management  office  (PMO)  has  been  established 
under the implementing agency and it is staffed with experienced people, some with experience 
of  projects  financed  by  ADB  and  the  World  Bank.19 The  PMO  will  oversee  and  manage  the 
implementation  of  all  project  activities  under  the  guidance  of  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies. The PMO will be responsible for all procurement activities under the project, and will 
select  an  experienced  procurement  agent  (tendering  company)  to  support  the  procurement 
activities. The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail 
in the project administration manual.20

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

26. 
The project includes highways of class I, II, III, and IV (PRC road standard classes). The 
design  for  the  S203  highway  will  be  based  on  class  I  highway  standard,  with  appropriate 
adjustments,  particularly  safety  features,  to  allow  two-way  traffic.  Road  safety  audits  will  be 
conducted  on  the  detailed  designs  during  and  after  construction  to  ensure  compliance  with 
required  road  safety  standards.  The  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  is 
considered adequate to implement the project’s technical aspects based on the performance on 
past projects. The due diligence highlighted the need to factor-in the hydrological and ecological 
functions of the wetlands in the detailed bridge designs. A hydrologist and design engineer will 
assist and advise the PMO on this aspect.  

B. 

Economic and Financial 

27. 
The  project  is  economically  viable.  Its  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is 
13.2%  and  the  net  present  economic  value  is  $37.9  million  at  a  12%  discount  rate.  Improved 
driving  conditions  due  to  smoother  road  surfaces  will  shorten  travel  times  by  5%–50% 
depending  on  vehicle  type  and  road  section.  Vehicle  operating  costs  will  be  reduced.  In  the 
case of road sections upgraded from dirt track to paved road standard, vehicle operating costs 
will be up to 35% lower. Shorter travel time and reduced vehicle operating costs will enable local 
economic development and facilitate development of cross-border trade. The economic internal 
rate of return is robust to increases in capital costs but sensitive to traffic growth assumptions. 
The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  understates  the  expected  economic  contribution  of  the 
project since it is also expected to have significant unquantified benefits, particularly for cross-
border trade with the eastern part of Mongolia.  

28. 
The  project  roads  will  be  constructed  and  operated  by  the  IMDT,  which  is  a 
noncommercial  government  agency,  and  will  be  nonrevenue  earning.  The  financial  analysis 
confirmed  that  the  IMDT  will  have  sufficient  revenues  to  repay  the  loan  and  finance  the 
operation and maintenance of the project roads.

D. 

Poverty and Social 

30. 
A social impact analysis was conducted in accordance with ADB guidelines. While IMAR 
has achieved high economic growth, rural per capita incomes lag behind the rest of the PRC. In 
2011, the average per capita income in rural areas was CNY6,642, which was lower than in the 
neighboring  provinces  of  Heilongjiang,  Jilin,  and  Liaoning. 24  One  of  the  three  project  qi 
(counties), Xinzuo Qi, is designated poor under the provincial poverty criteria. Using the IMAR 
poverty standard of CNY3,100 for the rural population, the rural poverty rate in 2011 was 59.5% 
for  Xinzuo  Qi  and  25.5%  for  Xinyou  Qi. 25 Poor  infrastructure,  lack  of  nonfarm  employment 
opportunities and skills, and frequent natural disasters such as snowstorms are among the main 
causes of poverty. 

31. 
The project will result in better road connectivity, reduce various transport-related costs 
and  travel  time,  and  improve  access  to  economic  and  employment  opportunities  and  social 
services.  It  will  stimulate  investment  in  the  area  and  promote  industrial  growth,  cross-border 
trade, tourism  development,  and  nonfarm  employment.  Rural roads  will  improve the  access of 
rural communities to more diverse, nonpastoral livelihoods and  will also result in higher profits 
from  livestock  and  farm  products.  Rural  roads  will  ensure  year-round  road  connectivity, 
including  rescue  and  relief  operations  during  snowstorms,  enhancing  the  resilience  of  local 
people to such shocks that often result in their impoverishment. 

32. 
Gender.  Within  the  project  area,  women  have  particular  transport  needs  arising  from 
their  various  gender  roles  and  patterns  of  mobility,  and  from  combining  farm  work  and/or 
employment  with  travel  to  markets,  health  clinics,  and  other  services.  To  ensure  that  women 
benefit equally, a gender action plan will be implemented to ensure that women (i) participate in 
project  activities  and  decision-making  processes;  (ii)  benefit  from  employment  opportunities 
created  by  the  project;  and  (iii)  participate  in  capacity  development  measures,  particularly 
improvement  measures  such  as  community-based  ecotourism  development.

35. 
The  Hulunbeier  grasslands  and  the  reserve  are  considered  critical  habitat  under  the 
Safeguard Policy Statement. In line with the requirements of the Safeguard Policy Statement for 
projects  in  critical  habitats  and  protected  areas,  specialist  studies  were  carried  out  to 
demonstrate  that  there  will  be  no  measurable  adverse  impacts  on  critical  habitats  and  to 
develop  a  support  program  for  the  reserve.  The  program  includes  three  subcomponents: 
(i) managing  and  raising  the  awareness  of  road  users,  (ii)  ecological  management  and 
monitoring, and (iii) eco-cultural tourism demonstration. The program is intended to promote and 
enhance the conservation aims of the protected area, offset induced impacts of the project, and 
achieve  a  net  gain  for  biodiversity.  The  project  area  is  in  a  permafrost  zone,  so  the  risks  of 
permafrost  degradation  and  considerations  for  road  design  and  maintenance  have  been 
assessed.  Current  climate  change  projections  indicate  that  permafrost  in  the  project  area  is 
unlikely to degrade until the end of the century. 

36. 
Involuntary resettlement. Seven project roads will result in permanent land acquisition 
of  15,680  mu  and  will  partially  affect  792  people.27 Almost  93%  of  the  land  to  be  acquired  is 
grassland,  most  of  which  is  already  degraded  and  its  acquisition  will  have  little  impact  on  the 
livelihood of the affected people. The project will also result in demolition of two unused houses 
(175 square meters) affecting seven people, and part of a disused cement factory affecting 98 
people.  The  affected  people  will  be  compensated  for  their  losses.  Four  resettlement  plans 
prepared by the Hulunbeier Bureau of Transport in accordance with Safeguard Policy Statement 
adequately address the land acquisition and resettlement impacts and are based on substantive 
consultation  with  affected  people. The IMDT  has  assured that  it  will  implement  the  involuntary 
resettlement  safeguard  measures  set  out  in  the  resettlement  plans,  including  providing 
budgetary resources. The resettlement plans have been disclosed to the affected people and on 
the  ADB  website.  The  IMDT  has  relevant  experience  in  implementing  social  safeguards,  and 
additional  capacity  development support for  social  safeguards  implementation  is  also  included 
in the project.  

37.

minority community, mainly living in rural areas. Village and household surveys indicate that the 
ethnic  minority  community  supports  the  project.  Improved  rural  roads  will  be  particularly 
beneficial  for  the  ethnic  minority  community,  ensuring  better  access  to  social  services  and 
nonfarm  employment  opportunities,  higher  profitability  from  livestock  and  farm  products,  and

treatment  for  project-generated  employment  opportunities.  Potential  negative  impacts  include

culture and customs. To avoid and mitigate these impacts, an ethnic minority development plan
